We explore the effect of a transformation \\( f(z) = e^{nt}z \\), applied at different times, where \\( n \\) is another complex number.

If at a specific time \\( t_1 \\), a new transformation \\( g(z) = e^{pt}z \\) (where \\( p \\) is a complex number) is applied as an intervention, will the final state \\( z(T) \\) for T > t_1 only depend on \\( k \\) and not on \\( m, n \\) or \\( p \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( g(z) \\) at \\( t_1 \\) further alters the trajectory initiated by \\( f(z) \\), making the endpoint \\( z(T) \\) a product of interactions between \\( m, n, p, \\) and \\( k \\). Each exponent contributes differently, influencing both magnitude and phase of the solution.
